instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: Why does EnergyPlus use load-based control instead of temperature-based control?
output: EnergyPlus uses load-based control because it needs to function at zone timesteps up to one hour which is too long for true temperature-based zone control.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is load-based control used for?
output: Load-based control is an important method of determining the average HVAC system response to zone conditions over the time step.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How is operative temperature control achieved in EnergyPlus?
output: For operative temperature control the same methods and routines are used for calculating loads to setpoints but the setpoints are shifted to emulate operative temperature control rather than air temperature control.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is the user-defined setpoint for \(T_OP\)?
output: The user-defined setpoint for \(T_OP\) is an input in degrees Celsius.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How is \(T_MRT\) modeled?
output: \(T_MRT\) is continually modeled by the full zone heat balance method and includes all the interactions between thermal loads and HVAC systems.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How is a new setpoint for \(T_drybulb\) obtained?
output: A new setpoint for the zone's \(T_drybulb\) is obtained for each zone timestep by rearranging the definition of \(T_OP\) to put \(T_drybulb\) on the left-hand side.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating \(T_drybulbsetpoint\)?
output: \(T_drybulbsetpoint = \fracT_OPsetpoint - \gamma T_MRT(1 - \gamma )\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: When is the adjustment to the target zone air drybulb temperature made?
output: This adjustment to the target zone air drybulb temperature is made every timestep for every zone immediately after the setpoints are obtained from the schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is the reference for integrating radiant/operative temperature controls?
output: Reference: J. Niu and J. Burnett. 1998. Integrating Radiant/Operative Temperature Controls into Building Energy Simulations. ASHRAE Transactions Vol. 104. Part 2. page 210. ASHRAE. Atlanta GA.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is the purpose of the input object ZoneControl:Thermostat:TemperatureAndHumidity?
output: The input object ZoneControl:Thermostat:TemperatureAndHumidity is used to modify the behavior of ZoneControl:Thermostat objects based on zone air humidity conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How does TemperatureAndHumidity zone control affect the cooling setpoint temperature?
output: This TemperatureAndHumidity zone control resets the ZoneControl:Thermostat's cooling setpoint temperature downward when the zone air relative humidity exceeds the Dehumidifying Relative Humidity Setpoint defined in this object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is the effect of reducing the cooling setpoint temperature?
output: The reduced cooling setpoint temperature typically results in longer cooling coil runtimes and additional dehumidification.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What determines if the zone air relative humidity is reduced?
output: The resulting dry-bulb temperature and absolute humidity of the zone air will determine if the zone air relative humidity is reduced.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What dictates the rate at which the cooling setpoint temperature is reduced?
output: The rate at which the cooling setpoint temperature is reduced is dictated by the user-specified Overcool Control Ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What defines the maximum reduction in cooling setpoint temperature?
output: The maximum reduction in cooling setpoint temperature is defined by the user-entered Overcool Range.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What should be noted about the Overcool Range?
output: The Overcool Range may be reduced from the user-defined value when this TemperatureAndHumidity control is used in tandem with a dual setpoint thermostat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is a potential issue with overcooling?
output: Occupants are sensitive to overcooling and can experience discomfort if the overcool range is too large.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> equation
input: What is the equation used to adjust the target zone air drybulb temperature?
output: = \\fracT_OPsetpoint - \\gamma T_MRT(1 - \\gamma )

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: When is the adjustment to the target zone air drybulb temperature made?
output: This adjustment to the target zone air drybulb temperature is made every timestep for every zone immediately after the setpoints are obtained from the schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What reference is provided for integrating radiant/operative temperature controls into building energy simulations?
output: Reference: J. Niu and J. Burnett. 1998. Integrating Radiant/Operative Temperature Controls into Building Energy Simulations. ASHRAE Transactions Vol. 104. Part 2. page 210. ASHRAE. Atlanta GA.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is the purpose of the input object ZoneControl:Thermostat:TemperatureAndHumidity?
output: The input object ZoneControl:Thermostat:TemperatureAndHumidity is used to modify the behavior of ZoneControl:Thermostat objects (control types ThermostatSetpoint:SingleCooling and ThermostatSetpoint:DualSetpoint only) based on zone air humidity conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How does the TemperatureAndHumidity zone control affect the cooling setpoint temperature?
output: This TemperatureAndHumidity zone control resets the ZoneControl:Thermostat's cooling setpoint temperature downward when the zone air relative humidity exceeds the Dehumidifying Relative Humidity Setpoint defined in this object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is the typical result of reducing the cooling setpoint temperature?
output: The reduced cooling setpoint temperature typically results in longer cooling coil runtimes and additional dehumidification.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What determines if the zone air relative humidity is reduced?
output: The resulting dry-bulb temperature and absolute humidity of the zone air will determine if the zone air relative humidity is reduced.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What dictates the rate at which the cooling setpoint temperature is reduced?
output: The rate at which the cooling setpoint temperature is reduced is dictated by the user-specified Overcool Control Ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What defines the maximum reduction in cooling setpoint temperature?
output: The maximum reduction in cooling setpoint temperature is defined by the user-entered Overcool Range although the Overcool Range may be reduced from the user-defined value when this TemperatureAndHumidity control is used in tandem with a dual setpoint thermostat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is a potential consequence of a large overcool range?
output: Note that occupants are sensitive to overcooling and can experience discomfort if the overcool range is too large.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How is the control accomplished in EnergyPlus?
output: This control is accomplished using the load to setpoint formulation that is fundamental to HVAC system control in EnergyPlus.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: Why is load-based control important in EnergyPlus?
output: Load-based control is an important method of determining the average HVAC system response to zone conditions over the time step.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus handle TemperatureAndHumidity control?
output: For TemperatureAndHumidity control the same methods and routines are used for calculating loads to setpoints but the cooling setpoint is shifted to emulate TemperatureAndHumidity control.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What limits the extent of the zone air temperature reduction below the cooling setpoint?
output: The overcool range limits the extent of the zone air temperature reduction below the cooling setpoint.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What must the maximum overcool range be when a dual setpoint thermostat is modified by TemperatureAndHumidity control?
output: The maximum overcool range must be less than or equal to the temperature difference between the dual setpoint thermostat's cooling and heating setpoints.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> equation
input: What is the equation for the maximum overcool range for the zone air?
output: \\Delta T_OvercoolRangeMAX = MIN \\left( \\Delta T_OvercoolRange\\Delta T_Setpoints \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is \\(\\Delta T_OvercoolRangeMAX\\)?
output: \\(\\Delta T_OvercoolRangeMAX\\) is the maximum overcool range for the zone air (\\(^\\circ\\)C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is \\(\\Delta T_OvercoolRange\\)?
output: \\(\\Delta T_OvercoolRange\\) is a user input for the overcool range for the zone air (\\(^\\circ\\)C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is \\(\\Delta T_Setpoints\\)?
output: \\(\\Delta T_Setpoints\\) is the temperature difference between the cooling and heating setpoints (\\(^\\circ\\)C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is the maximum overcool range if a single cooling setpoint thermostat is modified by this control?
output: If a single cooling setpoint thermostat is being modified by this control the maximum overcool range is equal to the user-defined overcool range.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> equation
input: What is the equation for the extent that the zone air relative humidity exceeds the dehumidifying relative humidity setpoint?
output: \\Delta \\phi = MAX \\left( 0.0\\phi_ZoneLagged - \\phi_CSP \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: Why does EnergyPlus need to function at zone timesteps up to one hour?
output: Because real systems will not know the loads and operate on temperature-based control and one hour is too long for true temperature-based zone control.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is the importance of load-based control in EnergyPlus?
output: Load-based control is an important method of determining the average HVAC system response to zone conditions over the time step.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How is the cooling setpoint shifted for TemperatureAndHumidity control?
output: For TemperatureAndHumidity control the same methods and routines are used for calculating loads to setpoints but the cooling setpoint is shifted to emulate TemperatureAndHumidity control.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What limits the extent of the zone air temperature reduction below the cooling setpoint?
output: The overcool range limits the extent of the zone air temperature reduction below the cooling setpoint.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What condition must be met for the maximum overcool range when a dual setpoint thermostat is modified by TemperatureAndHumidity control?
output: The maximum overcool range must be less than or equal to the temperature difference between the dual setpoint thermostat's cooling and heating setpoints.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> equation
input: What is the equation for the maximum overcool range for the zone air?
output: The equation is: \\( \\Delta T_OvercoolRangeMAX = MIN \\left( \\Delta T_OvercoolRange\\Delta T_Setpoints \\right) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\(\\Delta T_OvercoolRangeMAX\\) represent?
output: \\(\\Delta T_OvercoolRangeMAX\\) is the maximum overcool range for the zone air (°C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\(\\Delta T_OvercoolRange\\) represent?
output: \\(\\Delta T_OvercoolRange\\) is a user input for the overcool range for the zone air (°C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\(\\Delta T_Setpoints\\) represent?
output: \\(\\Delta T_Setpoints\\) is the temperature difference between the cooling and heating setpoints (°C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is the maximum overcool range if a single cooling setpoint thermostat is modified by this control?
output: The maximum overcool range is equal to the user-defined overcool range.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> equation
input: What is the equation for the extent that the zone air relative humidity exceeds the user-entered dehumidifying relative humidity setpoint?
output: The equation is: \\( \\Delta \\phi = MAX \\left( 0.0\\phi_ZoneLagged - \\phi_CSP \\right) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> equation
input: What is the equation for the actual cooling setpoint reduction (overcooling) when the zone air relative humidity exceeds the dehumidifying setpoint?
output: The equation is: \\( \\beginarrayl IF~(\\Delta \\phi~>~0)~THEN \\\\ ~~\\Delta T_OvercoolActual = MIN \\left( \\Delta T_OvercoolRangeMAX\\Delta \\phi  / \\Delta \\phi_adjust \\right) \\\\ ELSE \\\\ ~~\\Delta T_OvercoolActual = 0 \\\\ END IF \\endarray \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> equation
input: What is the equation to adjust the cooling setpoint temperature?
output: The equation is: \\( T_CSPadj = \\left( T_CSP - \\Delta T_OvercoolActual \\right) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\(T_CSPadj\\) represent?
output: \\(T_CSPadj\\) is the adjusted cooling setpoint temperature (°C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\(T_CSP\\) represent?
output: \\(T_CSP\\) is the user input for zone air cooling setpoint temperature for the current time step (°C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\(\\Delta \\phi_adjust\\) represent?
output: \\(\\Delta \\phi_adjust\\) is the user-defined overcool control ratio (%/K).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\(\\Delta \\phi\\) represent?
output: \\(\\Delta \\phi\\) is the difference between the zone air relative humidity and the user-defined dehumidifying setpoint (%).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\(\\phi_ZoneLagged\\) represent?
output: \\(\\phi_ZoneLagged\\) is the zone air relative humidity calculated at the last system time step (%).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\(\\varphi_CSP\\) represent?
output: \\(\\varphi_CSP\\) is the user input for the dehumidifying relative humidity setpoint at the current time step (%).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: When is the adjusted cooling setpoint temperature made?
output: This adjusted cooling setpoint temperature is made every timestep for every zone immediately after the original thermostat setpoint is obtained from the user-defined setpoint schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does the input object ZoneControl:Humidistat provide?
output: The input object ZoneControl:Humidistat provides a way for the zone to be controlled to a single relative humidity setpoint schedule or dual humidity schedules (humidifying and dehumidifying with deadband).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What do the schedules for ZoneControl:Humidistat consist of?
output: The schedules consist of relative humidities expressed as a percentage (0-100) to be used for the zone moisture prediction calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How many control statements can be specified for each zone using ZoneControl:Humidistat?
output: Only one control statement can be specified for each zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What flexibility does ZoneControl:Humidistat offer in terms of relative humidity values?
output: Individual relative humidity values can be defined for every time step giving the user a full range of flexibility.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What happens if the control relative humidity is below the calculated load and the equipment can humidify?
output: If the control relative humidity is below the calculated load and the equipment specified can humidify then that equipment will try and meet the requirement.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> equation
input: What is the equation for determining the actual overcooling temperature difference?
output: The equation is: \\( \\Delta T_OvercoolActual = MIN \\left( \\Delta T_OvercoolRangeMAX\\Delta \\phi  / \\Delta \\phi_adjust \\right) \\) ELSE \\( \\Delta T_OvercoolActual = 0 \\) END IF.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How is the cooling setpoint temperature adjusted?
output: The cooling setpoint temperature is adjusted as follows: \\( T_CSPadj = \\left( T_CSP - \\Delta T_OvercoolActual \\right) \\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> equation
input: What is the equation for the adjusted cooling setpoint temperature?
output: The equation is: \\( T_CSPadj = \\left( T_CSP - \\Delta T_OvercoolActual \\right) \\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\( T_CSPadj \\) represent?
output: \\( T_CSPadj \\) is the adjusted cooling setpoint temperature (\\(^\\circ\\)C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\( T_CSP \\) represent?
output: \\( T_CSP \\) is the user input for zone air cooling setpoint temperature for the current time step (\\(^\\circ\\)C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\( \\Delta \\phi_adjust \\) represent?
output: \\( \\Delta \\phi_adjust \\) is the user-defined overcool control ratio (\\%/K).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\( \\Delta \\phi \\) represent?
output: \\( \\Delta \\phi \\) is the difference between the zone air relative humidity and the user-defined dehumidifying setpoint (\\%).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\( \\phi_ZoneLagged \\) represent?
output: \\( \\phi_ZoneLagged \\) is the zone air relative humidity calculated at the last system time step (\\%).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does \\( \\varphi_CSP \\) represent?
output: \\( \\varphi_CSP \\) is the user input for the dehumidifying relative humidity setpoint at the current time step (\\%).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How often is the adjusted cooling setpoint temperature made?
output: This adjusted cooling setpoint temperature is made every timestep for every zone immediately after the original thermostat setpoint is obtained from the user-defined setpoint schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: What is the purpose of the ZoneControl:Humidistat input object?
output: The input object ZoneControl:Humidistat provides a way for the zone to be controlled to a single relative humidity setpoint schedule or dual humidity schedules (humidifying and dehumidifying with deadband).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: What do the schedules consist of in the ZoneControl:Humidistat?
output: The schedules consist of relative humidities expressed as a percentage (0-100) to be used for the zone moisture prediction calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: How many control statements can be specified for each zone?
output: Only one control statement can be specified for each zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: Can individual relative humidity values be defined for every time step?
output: Yes individual relative humidity values can be defined for every time step thus giving the user a full range of flexibility.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: What happens in a single setpoint humidistat if the control relative humidity is below the calculated load?
output: If the control relative humidity is below the calculated load and the equipment specified can humidify then that equipment will try and meet the requirement.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: What happens if the calculated value is above the setpoint in a single setpoint humidistat?
output: If the calculated value is above the setpoint and the equipment can dehumidify the equipment will try to meet the requirement.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: What happens in a dual setpoint humidistat if the zone relative humidity is below the humidifying setpoint?
output: If the zone relative humidity is below the humidifying relative humidity setpoint and the equipment specified can humidify then that equipment will try and meet the zone's humidification load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: What happens if the zone relative humidity is above the dehumidifying setpoint in a dual setpoint humidistat?
output: If the zone relative humidity is above the dehumidifying relative humidity setpoint and the equipment can dehumidify the equipment will try to meet the requirement.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: What is required if the ZoneControl:Humidistat is used by a furnace or unitary system?
output: If the ZoneControl:Humidistat is used by a furnace or unitary system then no other objects are required. The signal from the humidistat is used directly by that component.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: What objects are required if the ZoneControl:Humidistat is used with a Humidifier or Controller:Simple?
output: If the ZoneControl:Humidistat is used to control a Humidifier or used in conjunction with the Controller:Simple object with control variable \TemperatureAndHumidityRatio\ then either the \SetpointManager:SingleZone:Humidity:Minimum\ \SetpointManager:MultiZone:Humidity:Minimum\ \SetpointManager:SingleZone:Humidity:Maximum\ or \SetpointManager:MultiZone:Humidity:Maximum\ objects are required to determine a setpoint for those components to meet for the single setpoint humidistat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: What is required for a dual setpoint humidistat?
output: For a dual setpoint humidistat a minimum humidity setpoint manager object (\SetpointManager:SingleZone:Humidity:Minimum\ or \SetpointManager:MultiZone:Humidity:Minimum\) and a maximum humidity setpoint manager object (\SetpointManager:SingleZone:Humidity:Maximum\ or \SetpointManager:MultiZone:Humidity:Maximum\) are required to determine the setpoints for the corresponding humidification and dehumidification components.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: What can the SetpointManager:Scheduled object be used for?
output: The SetpointManager:Scheduled object can also be used to directly set humidity ratio setpoints on the exit node of the humidifier component.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: What does the model take into account for the single setpoint humidistat case?
output: For the single setpoint humidistat case the model takes into account all of the moisture gains and/or losses from sources except the HVAC system contribution and then calculates a moisture removal or addition rate based on the provided setpoint value like the temperature predictor.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Humidistat -> text
input: What algorithm is used to predict zone moisture addition or removal?
output: The algorithm uses a 3rd Order derivative to predict zone moisture addition or removal to smooth the changes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What happens if the zone relative humidity is below the humidifying relative humidity setpoint in a dual setpoint humidistat?
output: If the zone relative humidity is below the humidifying relative humidity setpoint and the equipment specified can humidify then that equipment will try and meet the zone's humidification load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What occurs if the zone relative humidity is above the dehumidifying relative humidity setpoint?
output: If the zone relative humidity is above the dehumidifying relative humidity setpoint and the equipment can dehumidify the equipment will try to meet the zone's dehumidification load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: Is any additional object required if the ZoneControl:Humidistat is used by a furnace or unitary system?
output: No other objects are required if the ZoneControl:Humidistat is used by a furnace or unitary system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is required if the ZoneControl:Humidistat is used to control a Humidifier or used with the Controller:Simple object?
output: Either the SetpointManager:SingleZone:Humidity:Minimum SetpointManager:MultiZone:Humidity:Minimum SetpointManager:SingleZone:Humidity:Maximum or SetpointManager:MultiZone:Humidity:Maximum objects are required to determine a setpoint for those components to meet for the single setpoint humidistat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What is needed for a dual setpoint humidistat to determine setpoints for humidification and dehumidification components?
output: A minimum humidity setpoint manager object (SetpointManager:SingleZone:Humidity:Minimum or SetpointManager:MultiZone:Humidity:Minimum) and a maximum humidity setpoint manager object (SetpointManager:SingleZone:Humidity:Maximum or SetpointManager:MultiZone:Humidity:Maximum) are required.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: Can the SetpointManager:Scheduled object be used in humidity control?
output: Yes the SetpointManager:Scheduled object can be used to directly set humidity ratio setpoints on the exit node of the humidifier component.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How does the model handle moisture gains or losses for the single setpoint humidistat case?
output: The model takes into account all moisture gains and/or losses from sources except the HVAC system contribution and calculates a moisture removal or addition rate based on the provided setpoint value.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What algorithm does the model use to predict zone moisture changes?
output: The algorithm uses a 3rd Order derivative to predict zone moisture addition or removal to smooth the changes using the zone air capacitance.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What do positive and negative moisture load values indicate?
output: Positive values of moisture load mean that this amount of moisture must be added to the zone to reach the setpoint while negative values represent the amount of moisture that must be removed by the system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> equation
input: What is the equation for MoistLoadHumidSetPoint?
output: MoistLoadHumidSetPoint = massflow \\cdot HumidityRatio = kg~air/s \\cdot kg~H_2O / kg~air = kg~H_2O/s

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does the routine calculate in addition to zone required humidity ratio?
output: The routine calculates the zone required humidity ratio Wsetpoint which takes into account the zone multiplier.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: Is Wsp stored in a derived type for SetpointManagers?
output: No at this time the Wsp is not stored in a derived type to make it available for SetpointManagers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How does the model handle moisture gains or losses for the dual setpoint humidistat case?
output: The model takes into account all moisture gains and/or losses from sources except the HVAC system contribution and calculates moisture addition and removal rates based on the provided humidifying and dehumidifying setpoint values.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What methods are used in the algorithm to predict zone moisture changes?
output: The algorithm uses a Third Order Backward Difference Analytical Solution or Euler Method in subroutine CalcPredictedHumidityRatio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How are humidifying and dehumidifying moisture loads calculated?
output: The program calculates the humidifying (addition) and dehumidifying (removal) moisture loads based on the specified humidifying and dehumidifying setpoints respectively.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: Where is the calculated humidifying moisture load passed?
output: The calculated humidifying moisture load is passed to subroutine CalcSingZoneMinHumSetPoint and CalcMultiZoneMinHumSetPoint in the SetpointManager module.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: Where is the calculated dehumidifying moisture load passed?
output: The calculated dehumidifying moisture load is passed to subroutine CalcSingZoneMaxHumSetPoint and CalcMultiZoneMaxHumSetPoint in the SetpointManager module.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does a positive moisture load value indicate?
output: Positive values of moisture load mean that this amount of moisture must be added to the zone to reach the setpoint.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What do negative moisture load values represent?
output: Negative values represent the amount of moisture that must be removed by the system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> equation
input: What is the equation for MoistLoadHumidSetPoint?
output: MoistLoadHumidSetPoint = massflow \\cdot HumidityRatio = kg~air/s \\cdot kg~H_2O / kg~air = kg~H_2O/s

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does the routine calculate regarding the zone's humidity?
output: This routine also calculates the zone required humidity ratio Wsetpoint which is required and takes into account the zone multiplier.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: Is the Wsp stored in a derived type for SetpointManagers?
output: At this time the Wsp is not stored in a derived type to make it available for SetpointManagers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How is the dual setpoint humidistat case modeled?
output: For the dual setpoint humidistat case the model takes into account all of the moisture gains and/or losses from sources except the HVAC system contribution and then calculates moisture addition and removal rates based on the provided humidifying and dehumidifying setpoint values like the temperature predictor.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What methods are used in the algorithm to predict zone moisture changes?
output: The algorithm uses a Third Order Backward Difference Analytical Solution or Euler Method in subroutine CalcPredictedHumidityRatio to predict zone moisture addition and removal to smooth the changes using the zone air capacitance.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How are humidifying and dehumidifying moisture loads calculated?
output: The program calculates the humidifying (addition) and dehumidifying (removal) moisture loads based on the specified humidifying and dehumidifying setpoints respectively.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: Where is the calculated humidifying moisture load passed?
output: The calculated humidifying moisture load is passed to subroutine CalcSingZoneMinHumSetPoint and CalcMultiZoneMinHumSetPoint in the SetpointManager module to calculate the requested supply air humidity ratio at the setpoint node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: Where is the calculated dehumidifying moisture load passed?
output: The calculated dehumidifying moisture load is passed to subroutine CalcSingZoneMaxHumSetPoint and CalcMultiZoneMaxHumSetPoint in the SetpointManager module to calculate the requested supply air humidity ratio at the setpoint node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How does the system operate to meet the dehumidifying load?
output: At the same time the dehumidifying load is also passed directly to a furnace or unitary system if it is defined for the simulation and that system will operate to meet this load based on its configuration and control settings.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does the input object ZoneControl:Thermostat:ThermalComfort provide?
output: The input object ZoneControl:Thermostat:ThermalComfort provides a way for the zone to be controlled to a specified temperature based on a selected thermal comfort model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does ZoneControl:Thermostat:ThermalComfort reference?
output: ZoneControl:Thermostat:ThermalComfort references a thermal comfort control type schedule and one or more thermal comfort control type objects which in turn reference one or more setpoint schedules.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: How are the thermal comfort control type schedule and the list of thermal comfort control type/name pairs related?
output: The thermal comfort control type schedule and the list of thermal comfort control type/name pairs are directly related.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text
input: What does the schedule define in the ZoneControl:Thermostat:ThermalComfort?
output: The schedule defines the type of thermal comfort control that is to be used during each simulation time step.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Controls -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the ZoneHVAC:AirDistributionUnit?
output: The ZoneHVAC:AirDistributionUnit is a special piece of zone equipment that connects centrally conditioned air with a zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What types of air terminal units does the ZoneHVAC:AirDistributionUnit encompass?
output: It encompasses various types of air terminal units in EnergyPlus such as AirTerminal:DualDuct:ConstantVolume and AirTerminal:SingleDuct:VAV:Reheat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the purpose of the ZoneHVAC:AirDistributionUnit?
output: It is a generalized component that accesses the calculations for the different types of air terminal unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Which module encapsulates the air distribution function?
output: The air distribution function is encapsulated in the module ZoneAirEquipmentManager.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the function of the object and module in the air distribution system?
output: The object and module function only to invoke the individual air terminal unit simulations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What data does the air distribution unit require?
output: The data for this unit consists of the unit name the air outlet node name the type of air terminal unit and the name of the air terminal unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Where is all input data for air distribution units stored?
output: All input data for air distribution units is stored in the array AirDistUnit in data module DataDefineEquip.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What calculation is associated with ZoneHVAC:AirDistributionUnit?
output: There is no calculation associated with ZoneHVAC:AirDistributionUnit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Which function calls the individual air terminal unit simulations?
output: SimZoneAirLoopEquipment in module ZoneAirEquipmentManager calls the individual air terminal unit simulations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the mixer object AirTerminal:SingleDuct:Mixer provide?
output: The mixer object AirTerminal:SingleDuct:Mixer provides a means for using a ZoneHVAC equipment as a terminal unit by mixing central system conditioned air with the inlet or supply side air stream of the ZoneHVAC equipment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is usually the central system in the context of AirTerminal:SingleDuct:Mixer?
output: Usually the central system would be a Direct Outside Air System (DOAS) providing centrally conditioned ventilation air to the controlled zones.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is the inlet or supply side connection type specified?
output: The inlet or supply side connection type is specified by user.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What equations does the mixer use?
output: The mixer uses the equations for adiabatic mixing of two moist air streams including dry air mass balance water mass balance and enthalpy balance.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is known for inlet side mixer connection?
output: For inlet side mixer connection the primary air and outlet air flow rates are known and the condition of the primary and secondary air streams are also known.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the mass balance yield in the context of the mixer?
output: The mass balance yields the secondary air mass flow rate and the outlet conditions are determined from enthalpy and water mass balance.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is known for the supply side mixer connection?
output: For the supply side mixer connection the primary and secondary air stream conditions and flow rates are known so the outlet condition and flow rate is calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the only input data for the mixer?
output: The only input data are the name and type of the ZoneHVAC equipment unit plus the node names of the primary and the secondary air nodes and the outlet air node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Is any flow rate data needed for the mixer?
output: No flow rate data is needed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Where is all input data for the inlet and supply side mixer units stored?
output: All input data for the inlet and supply side mixer units is stored in the data structure SysATMixer.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for the enthalpy balance of two moist air streams?
output: \\dot m_da1h_1 + \\dot m_da2h_2 = \\dot m_da3h_3

output: The outlet air mass flow rate has been set by the zone HVAC equipment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text

output: The inlet or supply side connection type is specified by user.

output: The mixer uses the equations for adiabatic mixing of two moist air streams. Namely dry air mass balance water mass balance and enthalpy balance.

output: For inlet side mixer connection the primary air and outlet air flow rates are known and the condition of the primary and secondary air streams are also known.

output: The mass balance yields the secondary air mass flow rate and the outlet conditions are determined from enthalpy and water mass balance.

input: What is known for the supply side mixer connection?
output: For the supply side mixer connection the primary and secondary air stream conditions and flow rates are known so the outlet condition and flow rate is calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What are the only input data required for the ZoneHVAC equipment unit?
output: The only input data are the name and type of the ZoneHVAC equipment unit plus the node names of the primary and the secondary air nodes and the outlet air node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text

output: No flow rate data is needed.

output: All input data for the inlet and supply side mixer units is stored in the data structure SysATMixer.

output: \\( \\dot m_da1 + \\dot m_da2 = \\dot m_da3 \\)

input: What does \\(h\\) represent?
output: \\(h\\) is the specific enthalpy (J/kg).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is known for a mixer unit connected to the inlet side of a ZoneHVAC equipment?
output: For a mixer unit connected to the inlet side of a ZoneHVAC equipment the outlet air mass flow rate has been set by the zone HVAC equipment. The air mass flow rate of one of the inlets - the primary air from the central system - is also known.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is the secondary air mass flow rate obtained for a mixer unit connected to the inlet side?
output: The air mass balance equation is used to obtain the secondary air mass flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What inlet conditions are known for both inlet air streams?
output: The inlet conditions - specific enthalpy and humidity ratio - for both inlet air streams are known.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How are the outlet conditions determined once both inlet air streams mass flow rate is known?
output: The enthalpy and water mass balance equations are used to get the outlet conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is known for a mixer unit connected to the supply side of a ZoneHVAC equipment?
output: For a mixer unit connected to the supply side of a ZoneHVAC equipment the conditions and flow rates of the primary air and secondary air streams are known are taken from the inlet nodes data.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How are the outlet flow rate and conditions calculated for a supply side mixer connection?
output: The balance equations are then used to calculate the outlet flow rate and conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is the mixer model invoked within the zone HVAC model?
output: The mixer model is invoked from within the zone HVAC model. Basically the mixer becomes a subcomponent of the zone HVAC equipment model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the mixer allow the zone unit to do?
output: This allows the zone unit to allow for the mixing of central supply air with its inlet or supply air stream of the ZoneHVAC equipment in calculating how much cooling or heating it needs to do in order to meet the zone load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Where can references for the mixer model be found?
output: See Chapter 1 page 1.17 of the 2013 ASHRAE Handbook of Fundamentals.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the input object ZoneHVAC:AirDistributionUnit provide access to?
output: The input object ZoneHVAC:AirDistributionUnit also provides access to a model for duct leakage that can be a significant source of energy inefficiency in forced-air HVAC systems.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does evaluating duct leakage energy losses involve?
output: Evaluating duct leakage energy losses can involve considerable user effort and computer resources if an airflow network is defined through a detailed description of the system components and airflow paths (including leakage paths).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What type of solver is used to solve for pressures and flow rates in the network?
output: A nonlinear pressure-based solver is used to solve for pressures and flow rates in the network.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is used to obtain the secondary air mass flow rate?
output: The air mass balance equation is used to obtain the secondary air mass flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What are the known inlet conditions for both inlet air streams?
output: The known inlet conditions are specific enthalpy and humidity ratio for both inlet air streams.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What equations are used to get the outlet conditions once both inlet air streams mass flow rate is known?
output: The enthalpy and water mass balance equations are used to get the outlet conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What are known for a mixer unit connected to the supply side of ZoneHVAC equipment?
output: The conditions and flow rates of the primary air and secondary air streams are known.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is used to calculate the outlet flow rate and conditions?
output: The balance equations are used to calculate the outlet flow rate and conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Where is the mixer model invoked from?
output: The mixer model is invoked from within the zone HVAC model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the mixer become in the zone HVAC equipment model?
output: The mixer becomes a subcomponent of the zone HVAC equipment model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the zone unit allow for in calculating cooling or heating needs?
output: The zone unit allows for the mixing of central supply air with its inlet or supply air stream of the ZoneHVAC equipment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Where can references be found?
output: References can be found in Chapter 1 page 1.17 of the 2013 ASHRAE Handbook of Fundamentals.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the input object ZoneHVAC:AirDistributionUnit provide access to?
output: It provides access to a model for duct leakage.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What can evaluating duct leakage energy losses involve?
output: Evaluating duct leakage energy losses can involve considerable user effort and computer resources.

input: What is used to solve for pressures and flow rates in the network?
output: A nonlinear pressure-based solver is used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What are the assumptions for the leakage fraction C3 to remain constant?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What do the variables in the equations represent?
output: \\dot m_sus is the constant zone supply air mass flow rate upstream of the leaks (kg/s) \\dot m_tu is the air mass flow rate through the terminal unit (kg/s) \\dot m_lkus is the upstream leakage air mass flow rate (kg/s) \\dot m_lkds is the downstream leakage air mass flow rate (kg/s) \\dot m_susmax is the maximum upstream supply air mass flow rate (program input) (kg/s) \\dot m_sz is the supply air mass flow rate delivered to the zone (kg/s) Frac_us is the design upstream leakage fraction (program input) Frac_ds is the constant downstream leakage fraction (program input).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What are the sub-components of the 4 pipe fan coil unit model?
output: The 4 pipe fan coil unit is modeled as a compound component consisting of 4 sub-components: an outdoor air mixer a fan a cooling coil and a heating coil.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What EnergyPlus objects are used to model the 4 pipe fan coil unit?
output: The EnergyPlus objects are: OutdoorAir:Mixer Fan:ConstantVolume Coil:Cooling:Water Coil:Cooling:Water:DetailedGeometry or CoilSystem:Cooling:Water:HeatExchangerAssisted and Coil:Heating:Water or Coil:Heating:Electric.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is the 4 pipe fan coil unit described in terms of inputs?
output: The unit is a forward model: its inputs are defined by the state of its inlets: namely its 2 air streams -- recirculated and outdoor air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What are the outputs of the 4 pipe fan coil unit model?
output: The outputs of the model are the conditions of the outlet air stream: flow rate temperature and humidity ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Where is the unit data and simulation for the 4 pipe fan coil unit encapsulated?
output: The unit data and simulation are encapsulated in the module FanCoilUnits.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What inputs does the user need to provide for the 4 pipe fan coil unit?
output: The user describes the unit by inputting the names of the outdoor air mixer the fan the heating coil and the cooling coil. The heating and cooling coil types must also be specified.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is the 4 pipe fan coil unit connected to the overall HVAC system?
output: The unit is connected by specifying node names for the unit air inlet (for recirculated air) node air outlet node outdoor air node relief node inlet hot water node and inlet chilled water node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What must be ensured about the nodes in the fan coil unit?
output: The outdoor air mixer mixed air node must be the same as the fan inlet node; the fan outlet node must be the same as the cooling coil air inlet node; the cooling coil air outlet node must be the same as the heating coil air inlet node; and the heating coil air outlet node must be the same as the unit air outlet node; the outdoor air mixer inlet nodes must match the unit inlet nodes; and the outdoor air mixer relief node must match the unit relief node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What flow rates and tolerances must the user specify for the fan coil unit?
output: The user needs to specify various maximum flow rates: the supply air flow rate the outdoor air inlet flow rate the maximum (and minimum) chilled water flow rate and the maximum (and minimum) hot water flow rate. Heating and cooling convergence tolerances need to be specified or defaulted.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What availability schedule is needed for the fan coil unit?
output: There is an on/off availability schedule for the unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Where is all the input data for the fan coil unit stored?
output: All the input data for the fan coil unit is stored in the array FanCoil.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Where is the calculation for the 4 pipe fan coil unit performed?
output: The calculation is performed in subroutine Calc4PipeFanCoil.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text

output: The temperature humidity ratio and flow rate of the recirculated and outdoor air streams are taken from the inlet air nodes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text

output: The inlet hot and chilled water flow rates have been set by local controllers and temperatures are taken from the inlet water nodes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation

output: \\( \\dotQ_sensout = \\dotm_tot \\PB\\textPsyHFnTdbW\\PBT_outW_in - \\textPsyHFnTdbW\\PBT_inW_in \\)

output: The temperature humidity ratio and flow rate of the recirculated and outdoor air streams are taken from the inlet air nodes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Who sets the inlet hot and chilled water flow rates?
output: The inlet hot and chilled water flow rates have been set by local controllers.

output: The subscript 'in' indicates the conditions at the inlet recirculated air node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What do we obtain from the result of the zone simulation?
