instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is the phase angle between insolation and air temperature calculated?
output: The phase angle between the insolation and the air temperature (rad) \\varphi_I is calculated by subtracting insolation phase angle from air temperature phase angle.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the phase constant of the air?
output: The phase constant of the air (sec) t_0a is the time elapsed from the beginning of the year at which the air temperature reaches the minimum value in the year.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What variables are used to evaluate average soil surface temperature and related parameters?
output: By using all the input parameters and variables described average soil surface temperature (°C) T_m amplitude of the soil surface temperature variation (°C) A_s phase constant of the soil surface (sec) t_0 and phase angle difference between the air and soil surface temperature (rad) \\Phi_s can be evaluated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for evaluating average soil surface temperature T_m?
output: T_m = \\frac1h_e\\left[ h_rT_ma - \\varepsilon \\Delta R + \\beta S_m - 0.0168h_sfb\\left( 1 - r_a \\right) \\right]

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for evaluating amplitude of the soil surface temperature variation A_s?
output: A_s = \\left\\| \\frach_rT_va - \\beta S_ve^i\\phi_I\\left( h_e + \\delta k_s \\right) \\right\\|

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for evaluating the phase constant of the soil surface t_0?
output: t_0 = t_0a + \\frac\\phi_sw

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for evaluating phase angle difference between air and soil surface temperature φ_s?
output: \\phi_s = - Arg\\left[ \\frach_rT_va - \\beta S_ve^i\\phi_I\\left( h_e + \\delta k_s \\right) \\right]

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What do the symbols || and Arg denote?
output: The symbols || and Arg denote the modulus and the argument of a complex number respectively.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How can A_s and Φ_s be calculated?
output: In order to calculate A_s and Φ_s the complex number under consideration can be rearranged into a specified form.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the rearranged form of the complex number for calculating A_s and Φ_s?
output: \\beginarrayrl \\frach_r T_va - \\beta S_v e^i \\phi_Ih_e + \\delta k_s =& \\frac \\PBh_e + \\frack_sD \\PB h_r T_va - \\beta S_v \\cos \\phi_I + \\frack_sD \\PB-\\beta S_v \\sin \\phi_I\\PBh_e + \\frack_sD^2 + \\PB\\frack_sD^2 \\\\ &+ i\\frac \\PBh_e + \\frack_sD \\PB-\\beta S_v \\sin \\phi_I - \\frack_sD \\PBh_r T_va - \\beta S_v \\cos \\phi_I\\PBh_e + \\frack_sD^2 + \\PB\\frack_sD^2 \\endarray

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the assumption made in the Basic Model for estimating temperature at any depth and time?
output: Assuming a homogeneous soil of constant thermal diffusivity the temperature at any depth z and time t can be estimated by a specified expression.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the expression for estimating temperature at any depth z and time t in a homogeneous soil?
output: T_zt = T_m - A_s\\exp \\left[  - z\\left( \\frac\\pi \\rm365\\alpha_s \\right)^1/2 \\right]\\cos \\left\\ \\frac2\\pi \\rm365\\left[ t - t_0 - \\fracz2\\left( \\frac\\rm365\\pi \\alpha_s \\right)^1/2 \\right] \\right\\

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What units should be converted in the expression for temperature estimation?
output: The unit of time t and phase constant of the soil surface t_0 should be converted into days. Similarly the unit of soil thermal diffusivity \\alpha_s should also be converted.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for t_0 in the document?
output: t_0 = t_0a + \\frac\\phi_sw

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for φ_s in the document?
output: \\phi_s = - Arg\\left[ \\frach_rT_va - \\beta S_ve^i\\phi_I\\left( h_e + \\delta k_s \\right) \\right]

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What program calculates T_m A_s and t_0 and what is their role in EnergyPlus?
output: T_m A_s and t_0 are calculated by the CalcSoilSurfTemp program and are inputs to EnergyPlus. The remainder of this section describes what has been implemented in EnergyPlus.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What do the symbols || and Arg denote in the context of the document?
output: The symbols || and Arg denote the modulus and the argument of a complex number respectively.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the rearranged form of the complex number for calculating A_s and Φ_s?
output: \\frach_r T_va - \\beta S_v e^i \\phi_Ih_e + \\delta k_s = \\frac \\PBh_e + \\frack_sD \\PB h_r T_va - \\beta S_v \\cos \\phi_I + \\frack_sD \\PB-\\beta S_v \\sin \\phi_I\\PBh_e + \\frack_sD^2 + \\PB\\frack_sD^2 + i\\frac \\PBh_e + \\frack_sD \\PB-\\beta S_v \\sin \\phi_I - \\frack_sD \\PBh_r T_va - \\beta S_v \\cos \\phi_I\\PBh_e + \\frack_sD^2 + \\PB\\frack_sD^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What assumption is made in the Basic Model regarding ground temperature?
output: Assuming a homogeneous soil of constant thermal diffusivity the temperature at any depth z and time t can be estimated by a specified expression.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the expression for estimating temperature at any depth z and time t in the Basic Model?
output: T_zt = T_m - A_s\\exp \\left[  - z\\left( \\frac\\pi \\rm365\\alpha_s \\right)^1/2 \\right]\\cos \\left\\ \\frac2\\pi \\rm365\\left[ t - t_0 - \\fracz2\\left( \\frac\\rm365\\pi \\alpha_s \\right)^1/2 \\right] \\right\\

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How should the units of time t and phase constant of the soil surface t_0 be converted?
output: The unit of time t and phase constant of the soil surface t_0 should be converted into days.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How should the unit of soil thermal diffusivity α_s be converted?
output: The unit of soil thermal diffusivity α_s should be converted into m^2/days.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the Basic model for earth tubes used for?
output: In the Basic model for earth tubes the equation is used to calculate the temperature of the ground at the depth of the earth tube and this value is used to evaluate the heat transfer between the soil around the earth tube and the air passing through the earth tube.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the heat exchange in the Basic model involve?
output: This heat exchange involves determining convective heat transfer coefficient between the air passing through the earth tube and the surface of the tube itself converting this to a thermal resistance value and then adding on the thermal resistance for the earth tube pipe itself and the surrounding soil to the user defined distance to the 'undisturbed' region.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What are the required calculations regarding the thermal properties of air?
output: With regard to the heat transfer between soil and earth tube system thermal conductivity of air (W/m-°C) k_air and kinetic viscosity of air (m^2/s) ϑ should be calculated first.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the thermal conductivity of air k_air?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the kinetic viscosity of air ϑ?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How can the convective heat transfer coefficient at the inner pipe surface h_c be evaluated?
output: By using the values of thermal conductivity of air k_air and kinetic viscosity of air ϑ the convective heat transfer coefficient at the inner pipe surface (W/m^2-°C) h_c can be evaluated. It is a function of Reynolds number Re and Nusselt number Nu.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the convective heat transfer coefficient h_c?
output: h_c = \\fracNuk_air2r_1

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the Nusselt number Nu?
output: Nu = \\frac(f_a/2)(\\mathop\\rm Re\\nolimits - 1000)\\Pr 1 + 12.7(f_a/2)^1/2(\\Pr ^2/3 - 1)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the friction factor f_a?
output: f_a = (1.58\\ln \\mathop\\rm Re\\nolimits - 3.28)^ - 2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the Reynolds number Re?
output: \\mathop\\rm Re\\nolimits = \\frac2r_1V_a\\nu

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the Prandtl number Pr?
output: \\Pr = \\frac\\nu \\alpha_air

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What are the variables r_1 and V_a in the context of the document?
output: where r_1 is inner pipe radius (m) and V_a is average pipe air velocity (m/s).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the basic model for earth tubes used for?
output: In the Basic model for earth tubes the above equation is used to calculate the temperature of the ground at the depth of the earth tube and this value is used to evaluate the heat transfer between the soil around the earth tube and the air passing through the earth tube.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the heat exchange process involve in the earth tube model?
output: This heat exchange involves determining convective heat transfer coefficient between the air passing through the earth tube and the surface of the tube itself converting this to a thermal resistance value and then adding on the thermal resistance for the earth tube pipe itself and the surrounding soil to the user defined distance to the 'undisturbed' region.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What should be calculated first regarding the heat transfer between soil and earth tube system?
output: With regard to the heat transfer between soil and earth tube system thermal conductivity of air (W/m-°C) \(k_air\) and kinetic viscosity of air (m²/s) \(\upsilon\) should be calculated first.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating kinetic viscosity of air?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is the convective heat transfer coefficient at the inner pipe surface evaluated?
output: By using the values of thermal conductivity of air \(k_air\) and kinetic viscosity of air \(\upsilon\) the convective heat transfer coefficient at the inner pipe surface (W/m²-°C) \(h_c\) can be evaluated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What factors determine the convective heat transfer coefficient?
output: It is a function of Reynolds number Re and Nusselt number Nu.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the convective heat transfer coefficient?
output: \(h_c = \fracNuk_air2r_1\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the friction factor \(f_a\)?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the Reynolds number?
output: Re = \(\frac2r_1V_a\nu \)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the Prandtl number?
output: \(\Pr = \frac\nu \alpha_air\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What do the variables \(r_1\) and \(V_a\) represent?
output: Where \(r_1\) is inner pipe radius (m) and \(V_a\) is average pipe air velocity (m/s).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What are \(R_c\) \(R_p\) and \(R_s\) calculated for?
output: After determining the convective heat transfer coefficient \(R_c\) \(R_p\) and \(R_s\) are respectively calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating \(R_c\)?
output: \(R_c = \frac12\pi r_1h_c\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating \(R_p\)?
output: \(R_p = \frac12\pi k_p\ln \fracr_1 + r_2r_1\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating \(R_s\)?
output: \(R_s = \frac12\pi k_s\ln \fracr_1 + r_2 + r_3r_1 + r_2\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What do the variables \(R_c\) \(R_p\) and \(R_s\) represent?
output: Where \(R_c\) is thermal resistance due to convection heat transfer between the air in the pipe and the pipe inner surface (m-°C/W) \(R_p\) is thermal resistance due to conduction heat transfer between the pipe inner and outer surface (m-°C/W) and \(R_s\) is thermal resistance due to conduction heat transfer between the pipe outer surface and undisturbed soil (m-°C/W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What do the variables \(r_2\) \(r_3\) and \(L\) represent?
output: In addition \(r_2\) is pipe thickness (m) \(r_3\) is distance between the pipe outer surface and undisturbed soil (m) and \(L\) is pipe length (m).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the final step in evaluating heat transfer in the earth tube model?
output: Finally the heat transfer between the soil and the air inside the pipe is equal to the amount of heat losses as air flows along the pipe (Jacovides and Mihalakakou 1995).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for heat transfer between the soil and air inside the pipe?
output: \(U_t\\\left[ T_a(y) - T_zt \right]dy = - \dot m_aC_a\left[ dT_a(y) \right]\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for the overall heat transfer coefficient \(U_t\)?
output: \(U_t = \frac1R_t\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for total thermal resistance \(R_t\)?
output: \(R_t = R_c + R_p + R_s\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What do the variables \(U_t\) \(T_a(y)\) and \(m_a\) represent?
output: Where \(U_t\) is overall heat transfer coefficient of the whole earth tube system (W/m-°C) \(T_a(y)\) is air temperature of the pipe at the distance y from the pipe inlet (°C) and \(m_a\) is mass flow rate of ambient air through pipe (kg/s).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What do the variables \(C_a\) and \(R_t\) represent?
output: \(C_a\) is specific heat of air (J/kg-°C) and \(R_t\) is total thermal resistance between pipe air and soil (m-°C/W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the initial condition for inlet air temperature?
output: Initial condition of inlet air temperature is equal to the ambient air temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is the outlet air temperature evaluated?
output: Outlet air temperature is finally evaluated by solving the heat transfer equation above.

input: How are \(R_p\) and \(R_s\) calculated?
output: \(R_p\) and \(R_s\) are respectively calculated as follows:

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(R_c\)?
output: \(R_c = \frac12\pi r_1h_c\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(R_p\)?
output: \(R_p = \frac12\pi k_p\ln \fracr_1 + r_2r_1\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(R_s\)?
output: \(R_s = \frac12\pi k_s\ln \fracr_1 + r_2 + r_3r_1 + r_2\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is \(R_c\) in the context of thermal resistance?
output: \(R_c\) is thermal resistance due to convection heat transfer between the air in the pipe and the pipe inner surface (m-\(^\circ\)C/W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is \(R_p\) in the context of thermal resistance?
output: \(R_p\) is thermal resistance due to conduction heat transfer between the pipe inner and outer surface (m-\(^\circ\)C/W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is \(R_s\) in the context of thermal resistance?
output: \(R_s\) is thermal resistance due to conduction heat transfer between the pipe outer surface and undisturbed soil (m-\(^\circ\)C/W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is \(r_2\) in the context of pipe properties?
output: \(r_2\) is pipe thickness (m).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text

output: \(r_3\) is distance between the pipe outer surface and undisturbed soil (m).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is \(L\) in the context of pipe properties?
output: \emphL is pipe length (m).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the relationship between heat transfer and heat losses in the pipe?
output: The heat transfer between the soil and the air inside the pipe is equal to the amount of heat losses as air flows along the pipe (Jacovides and Mihalakakou 1995).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the heat transfer equation involving \(U_t\) and \(T_a(y)\)?
output: \(U_t\\\left[ T_a(y) - T_zt \right]dy = - \dot m_aC_a\left[ dT_a(y) \right]\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(U_t\)?
output: \(U_t = \frac1R_t\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(R_t\)?
output: \(R_t = R_c + R_p + R_s\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is \(U_t\) in the context of heat transfer?
output: \(U_t\) is overall heat transfer coefficient of the whole earth tube system (W/m-\(^\circ\)C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does \emphT\(_a\)(y) represent?
output: \emphT\(_a\)(y) is air temperature of the pipe at the distance y from the pipe inlet (\(^\circ\)C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does \(m_a\) represent?
output: \(m_a\) is mass flow rate of ambient air through pipe (kg/s).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does \(C_a\) represent?
output: \(C_a\) is specific heat of air (J/kg-\(^\circ\)C).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is \(R_t\) in the context of thermal resistance?
output: \(R_t\) is total thermal resistance between pipe air and soil (m-\(^\circ\)C/W).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the initial condition of inlet air temperature?
output: Initial condition of inlet air temperature is equal to the ambient air temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is the outlet air temperature evaluated?
output: Outlet air temperature is finally evaluated by solving the heat transfer equation above.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the Basic model in EnergyPlus calculate?
output: In EnergyPlus the Basic model simply calculates the ground temperature at the depth of the earth tube and assumes that the impact of the earth tube is minimal.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the Vertical model in EnergyPlus evaluate?
output: The Vertical model acknowledges that the soil temperature will be impacted by the presence of the heat transfer associated with the earth tube and looks to evaluate the impact that the earth tube air flow has on soil temperature in the vertical direction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the focus of the vertical model?
output: The vertical model focuses on the potential temperature variation in the vertical direction as a result of heat exchange between the ground around the earth tube and the air passing through it.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What mathematical approach is used to model vertical temperature variation?
output: The mathematical approach used to model vertical temperature variation due to the presence and heat transfer impact of the earth tube is a finite difference scheme.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the finite difference modeling technique involve?
output: This finite difference modeling technique looks at various nodes in the vertical direction and uses the following assumptions:

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the structure of the finite difference grid of nodes?
output: The finite difference grid of nodes contains a single row of nodes in the vertical direction only.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What are the boundary conditions of the finite difference grid?
output: The finite difference grid is bound at the top and the bottom with a temperature boundary condition. The temperature at the top and the bottom is variable and based on the undisturbed ground temperature equation used in the Basic model for the depth at the top and bottom of the domain.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Is there heat transfer in directions other than vertically for the nodes?
output: There is no heat transfer horizontally or axially for the nodes (adiabatic in all directions except vertically).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is heat transfer via conduction modeled?
output: Heat transfer via conduction is modeled between adjacent nodes in the vertical direction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Where is the impact of the air passing through the earth tube felt?
output: The impact of the air passing through the earth tube is felt at a single node the earth tube node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is the width of the solution horizontally set?
output: The width of the solution horizontally is set by user input.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What controls the number of nodes and height of the solution space?
output: The number of nodes above and below the earth tube node as well as how tall the solution space is above and below the earth tube is controlled by user input. These parameters will set the thickness of nodes above and below the earth tube node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the Basic model calculate regarding ground temperature?
output: The Basic model simply calculates the ground temperature at the depth of the earth tube and assumes that the impact of the earth tube is minimal.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How does the Vertical model differ in terms of soil temperature impact?
output: The Vertical model acknowledges that the soil temperature will be impacted by the presence of the heat transfer associated with the earth tube and looks to evaluate the impact that the earth tube air flow has on soil temperature in the vertical direction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What aspect does the vertical model focus on regarding soil temperature?
output: The vertical model focuses on the potential temperature variation in the vertical direction as a result of heat exchange between the ground around the earth tube and the air passing through it.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What mathematical approach is used in the vertical temperature variation model?
output: The mathematical approach used to model vertical temperature variation due to the presence and heat transfer impact of the earth tube is a finite difference scheme.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What assumptions are made in the finite difference modeling technique?
output: The assumptions include: a single row of nodes in the vertical direction only temperature boundary conditions at the top and bottom no heat transfer horizontally or axially conduction modeled between adjacent nodes vertically impact of air at a single node user-set horizontal width user-controlled number of nodes and height implicit finite difference solution scheme and nodal equations arranged as a matrix-based system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is the solution of the finite difference scheme initiated?
output: The solution of the finite difference scheme starts with the development of nodal equations throughout the solution space.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does the figure labeled 'Earth Tube Vertical Model Solution Space' represent?
output: The figure shows a representative nodal diagram for the Vertical earth tube model indicating the number of nodes above and below the earth tube.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the minimum and maximum number of nodes allowed above or below the earth tube?
output: The minimum number of nodes allowed either above or below the earth tube is 3 while the maximum is 10.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How many nodes are in the example shown in the figure?
output: The example shown has five nodes above the earth tube and four below.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How many types of nodes are there in the node diagram?
output: There are seven types of nodes in the node diagram.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What characterizes the nodes at the top and bottom of the solution space?
output: One node is at the top of the solution space in contact with the upper temperature boundary and the next node down and another node is at the bottom in contact with the lower temperature boundary and the next node up.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is unique about the equations for generic interior nodes?
output: The equations for generic interior nodes are very similar differing only in the height of the node which is based on user input.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What distinguishes the nodes adjacent to the earth tube node?
output: The nodes adjacent to the earth tube node differ in the size of the node height and the nodes to which they are connected.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What will the height of the earth tube node be set to?
output: The height of the earth tube node will be set to twice the diameter of the earth tube itself.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What solution scheme is used to promote stability in the earth tube model?
output: An implicit finite difference solution scheme is used to promote solution stability.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How are the nodal equations arranged in the earth tube model?
output: The nodal equations will be arranged as a matrix-based system of equations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the solution of the finite difference scheme for the Vertical model start with?
output: The solution of the finite difference scheme used for the Vertical model starts with the development of nodal equations throughout the solution space.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does the figure show in the context of the Vertical earth tube model?
output: The figure shows a representative nodal diagram for the Vertical earth tube model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How many nodes are allowed above or below the earth tube in the model?
output: The minimum number of nodes allowed either above or below the earth tube is 3 while the maximum is 10.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How many nodes are shown in the example for the earth tube model?
output: The example shown has five nodes above the earth tube and four below.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What are the types of nodes in the node diagram for the Vertical earth tube model?
output: There are seven types of nodes: a node at the top of the solution space a node at the bottom generic 'interior' nodes in the upper and lower areas nodes adjacent to the earth tube and the earth tube node itself.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What distinguishes the earth tube node from other nodes?
output: The earth tube node is different because it has a connection with conduction and convection to the air in the earth tube.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for Node Type 1: First Node (Below Upper Temperature Boundary)?
output: \\( \\rho x_t w L c_p \\fracT_1new - T_1old\\Delta t = k w L \\fracT_ut-T_1newx_t / 2 + k w L \\fracT_2new-T_1newx_t \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: How can the equation for Node Type 1 be rearranged?
output: \\( (1 + \\frac3 k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2) T_1new + (\\frac-k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2) T_2new = \\frac2 k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2 T_ut + T_1old \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is another form of the rearranged equation for Node Type 1?
output: \\( (1 + \\frac3 \\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2) T_1new + (\\frac-\\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2) T_2new = \\frac2 \\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2 T_ut + T_1old \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for Node Type 2: Generic Node Upper Region?
output: \\( \\rho x_t w L c_p \\fracT_inew - T_iold\\Delta t = k w L \\fracT_i+1new-T_inewx_t + k w L \\fracT_i-1new-T_inewx_t \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: How can the equation for Node Type 2 be rearranged?
output: \\( (\\frac-k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2) T_i+1new + (1 + \\frac2 k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2) T_inew + (\\frac-k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2) T_i+1new = T_iold \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is unique about the earth tube node in the grid?
output: The earth tube itself is an additional node type that is different than the other nodes due to the fact that it also has a connection with conduction and convection to the air in the earth tube.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the equation for each node type rearranged to fit?
output: Each node equation will be rearranged to fit with the matrix form: Ax = b where x is a vector of node temperatures.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the first node include in its equation?
output: The first node includes conduction between the upper boundary and the node as well as the second node and the first node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for the first node?
output: \\( \\rho x_t w L c_p \\fracT_1new - T_1old\\Delta t = k w L \\fracT_ut-T_1newx_t / 2 + k w L \\fracT_2new-T_1newx_t \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: How can the first node equation be rearranged?
output: \\( (1 + \\frac3 k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2) T_1new + (\\frac-k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2) T_2new = \\frac2 k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2 T_ut + T_1old \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is another rearrangement of the first node equation using \\(\\alpha_s\\)?
output: \\( (1 + \\frac3 \\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2) T_1new + (\\frac-\\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2) T_2new = \\frac2 \\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2 T_ut + T_1old \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the characteristic of the second through fourth nodes in the upper region?
output: The second through fourth nodes are all 'generic' nodes in the upper region with the same basic equation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for a generic node in the upper region?
output: \\( \\rho x_t w L c_p \\fracT_inew - T_iold\\Delta t = k w L \\fracT_i+1new-T_inewx_t + k w L \\fracT_i-1new-T_inewx_t \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: How can the generic node equation be rearranged?
output: \\( (\\frac-k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2) T_i+1new + (1 + \\frac2 k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2) T_inew + (\\frac-k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2) T_i+1new = T_iold \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is another rearrangement of the generic node equation using \\(\\alpha_s\\)?
output: \\( (\\frac-\\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2) T_i+1new + (1 + \\frac2 \\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2) T_inew + (\\frac-\\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2) T_i+1new = T_iold \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the last node in the upper region connect to?
output: The last node in the upper region connects to both the node above this one as well as the node at the earth tube ('et').

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Why does the last node in the upper region require a slight adjustment in the equations?
output: Because the thickness of the earth tube node and the nodes in the upper region are not the same.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for the last node in the upper region?
output: \\( \\rho x_t w L c_p \\fracT_et-1new - T_et-1old\\Delta t = k w L \\fracT_etnew-T_et-1new(x_t + x_et)/2 + k w L \\fracT_et-2new-T_et-1newx_t \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: How can the last node equation be rearranged?
output: \\( (\\frac-k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2) T_et-2new + [1 + \\frack \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2 + \\frack \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t (x_t+x_et)/2] T_et-1new + [\\frac-k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t (x_t+x_et)/2] T_etnew = T_et-1old \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is another rearrangement of the last node equation using \\(\\alpha_s\\)?
output: \\( (\\frac-\\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2) T_et-2new + [1 + \\frac\\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2 + \\frac\\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t (x_t+x_et)/2] T_et-1new + [\\frac-\\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t (x_t+x_et)/2] T_etnew = T_et-1old \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the earth tube node account for?
output: The earth tube node accounts for the convection between the air flowing through the tube and the conduction through the earth tube pipe material.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for the earth tube node?
output: \\( \\rho x_et w L c_p \\fracT_etnew - T_etold\\Delta t = k w L \\fracT_et+1new-T_etnew(x_b + x_et)/2 + k w L \\fracT_et-1new-T_etnew(x_t + x_et)/2 + \\dot m_aC_a \\eta (T_air - T_etnew) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the equation for the last node in the upper region?
output: The last node in the upper region connects to both the node above this one as well as the node at the earth tube ('et'). Since the thickness of the earth tube node and the nodes in the upper region are not the same this requires a slight adjustment in the equations for a different thickness in the vertical direction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for the last node in the upper region?
output: \\( \\rho x_t w L c_p \\fracT_et-1new - T_et-1old\\Delta t = k w L \\fracT_etnew-T_et-1new(x_t + x_et)/2 + k w L \\fracT_et-2new-T_et-1newx_t \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: How can the equation for the last node in the upper region be rearranged?
output: \\( (\\frac-k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2) T_et-2new + [1 + \\frack \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t^2 + \\frack \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t (x_t+x_et)/2] T_et-1new + [\\frac-k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_t (x_t+x_et)/2] T_etnew = T_et-1old \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is another form of the rearranged equation for the last node in the upper region?
output: \\( (\\frac-\\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2) T_et-2new + [1 + \\frac\\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t^2 + \\frac\\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t (x_t+x_et)/2] T_et-1new + [\\frac-\\alpha_s \\Delta tx_t (x_t+x_et)/2] T_etnew = T_et-1old \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the equation for the earth tube node?
output: The earth tube node is connected to nodes above and below it via conduction and also accounts for the convection between the air flowing through the tube and the conduction through the earth tube pipe material. The equation for this node assuming an effectiveness-NTU model for heat exchange between the air and ground is provided.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for the earth tube node?
output: \\( \\rho x_et w L c_p \\fracT_etnew - T_etold\\Delta t = k w L \\fracT_et+1new-T_etnew(x_b + x_et)/2 + k w L \\fracT_et-1new-T_etnew(x_t + x_et)/2 + \\dot m_aC_a \\eta (T_air - T_etnew) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: How can the equation for the earth tube node be rearranged?
output: \\( \\beginsplit [ \\frac-2k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_et (x_t + x_et) ] T_et-1new \\\\ + [ 1 + \\frac2 k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_et (x_t + x_et) + \\frac2 k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_et (x_b+x_et) + \\frac\\dot m_a C_a \\eta \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_et w L ] T_etnew \\\\ + [ \\frac-2k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_et (x_b + x_et) ] T_et+1new \\\\ = T_etold + \\frac\\dot m_a C_a \\eta \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_et w L T_airin \\endsplit \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is another form of the rearranged equation for the earth tube node?
output: \\( \\beginsplit [ \\frac-2 \\alpha_s \\Delta tx_et (x_t + x_et) ] T_et-1new \\\\ + [ 1 + \\frac2 \\alpha_s \\Delta tx_et (x_t + x_et) + \\frac2 \\alpha_s \\Delta tx_et (x_b+x_et) + \\frac\\dot m_a C_a \\eta \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_et w L ] T_etnew \\\\ + [ \\frac-2 \\alpha_s \\Delta tx_et (x_b + x_et) ] T_et+1new \\\\ = T_etold + \\frac\\dot m_a C_a \\eta \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_et w L T_airin \\endsplit \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the equation for the first node in the lower region?
output: The region below the earth tube node is physically very similar to the region above the earth tube. The main difference is the number of nodes and the overall thickness of the region can lead to a node height that is different than for the upper region.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for the first node in the lower region?
output: \\( \\rho x_b w L c_p \\fracT_et+1new - T_et+1old\\Delta t = k w L \\fracT_etnew-T_et+1new(x_b + x_et)/2 + k w L \\fracT_et+2new-T_et+1newx_b \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: How can the equation for the first node in the lower region be rearranged?
output: \\( [\\frac-k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_b (x_b + x_et)/2] T_etnew + [1 + \\frack \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_b^2 + \\frack \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_b (x_b+x_et)/2] T_et+1new + [\\frac-k \\Delta t\\rho c_p x_b^2] T_et+2new = T_et+1old \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for the first node in the upper region?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the description of Node Type 5: First Node in Lower Region?
output: The region below the earth tube node is physically very similar to the region above the earth tube (reflected in a sense at the earth tube itself). The main difference is the number of nodes and the overall thickness of the region can lead to a node height that is different than for the upper region. Above this first node in the lower region there is the earth tube node. Below it is one or more generic lower region nodes (Type 6 below).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the relationship between effectiveness and heat transfer between the air and ground?
output: Similar to the low temperature radiant system where a fluid of variable temperature is passing through a solid that is assumed to be at a single temperature the relationship between effectiveness and heat transfer between the air and the ground can be summarized using the following relationship.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for heat transfer between the air and the ground?
output: q = \\dot m_a * C_pa * (T_airin - T_airout)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What do the variables \(T_airin\) and \(T_airout\) represent?
output: where \(T_airin\) is the outside air temperature and \(T_airout\) is the temperature of the air leaving the earth tube and entering the zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for maximum heat transfer?
output: q_max = \\dot m_a * C_pa * (T_airin - T_et)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does \(T_et\) represent in the maximum heat transfer equation?
output: where \(T_et\) is the temperature of the ground at the depth of the earth tube (i.e. at the earth tube node).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: How is the effectiveness (\(\eta\)) defined in terms of heat transfer?
output: \\eta = \\fracqq_max

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How is effectiveness related to the number of transfer units (NTU) for a fluid of varying temperature flowing through a solid of constant temperature?
output: For the situation where a fluid of varying temperature flows through a solid of constant temperature the effectiveness can be related to the number of transfer units (NTU) by.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation relating effectiveness to NTU?
output: \\eta = 1 - e^-NTU

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: How is NTU calculated?
output: NTU = U A / (\\dot m C_p)_min

input: How is \((\\dot m C_p)_min\) evaluated when the solid is not moving?
output: Since the solid is not moving \((\\dot m C_p)_min\) is evaluated for the air side.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the vector x consist of in the matrix equation?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the vector b include in the matrix equation?
output: The vector b includes terms such as the old temperatures at the nodes the impact of boundary conditions at the top and bottom of the solution space and the impact of the earth tube on the earth tube node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Why do the values of vector b vary with every time step?
output: The values of vector b vary with every time step since the temperatures of the nodes ground and air will vary with time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What type of matrix is the A matrix?
output: Upon inspection it is clear that A will be a tridiagonal matrix.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What algorithm is used to solve tridiagonal matrices?
output: Tridiagonal matrices can be solved more efficiently using the Thomas algorithm.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Why is the Thomas algorithm preferred for solving tridiagonal matrices?
output: The Thomas algorithm requires operations on the order of the index (n) whereas solution strategies such as matrix inversion require operations on the order of the index (n) cubed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Which term in the A matrix might potentially vary?
output: The term associated with the air flow rate and efficiency of heat exchange between the earth tube and the air flow through it at the earth tube node might potentially vary.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What happens when there is no air flow through the earth tube?
output: The first step of the Thomas algorithm will be done for the zero flow situation and the values stored to reduce the number of calculations required by the solution.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Why is it not sensible to store an intermediate step in the solution for when effectiveness is unity?
output: While the earth tube is running the effectiveness (\( \eta \)) will be unity but the flow rate may still vary based on the user input flow coefficients. Therefore it does not make sense to store an intermediate step in the solution for when effectiveness is unity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the vector x represent?
output: The vector x consists of the new temperatures of the nodes using the implicit formulation for stability and the algorithm needs to solve for these.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What does the vector b include?

input: Why do the values of vector b vary with every time step?
output: The values of the vector b vary with every time step because the temperatures of the nodes ground and air will vary with time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the order of operations required by the Thomas algorithm compared to matrix inversion?
output: The Thomas algorithm requires operations on the order of the index (n) whereas matrix inversion requires operations on the order of the index (n) cubed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: Which term in the A matrix might potentially vary?
output: The term in the A matrix that might potentially vary is associated with the air flow rate and efficiency of heat exchange between the earth tube and the air flow through it at the earth tube node.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: When does the matrix system have to go through a full solution at any time step?
output: The matrix system will have to go through a full solution at any time step because it is not known ahead of time what the flow rate or efficiency will be.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the exception to the requirement of a full solution at any time step?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is done for the zero flow situation in the Thomas algorithm?
output: For the zero flow situation the first step of the Thomas algorithm is done and the values stored to reduce the number of calculations required by the solution.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What may still vary based on user input flow coefficients even when the earth tube is running?
output: The flow rate may still vary based on user input flow coefficients even when the earth tube is running.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is identical to the Basic earth tube model in many related calculations?
output: In many related calculations such as air flow rate and thermal properties of air the calculations are identical to the Basic earth tube model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: What is the main difference between the Basic model and the Vertical solution?
output: The main difference is the calculation of the temperature at the earth tube location; the Basic model uses the undisturbed ground temperature relationship while the Vertical solution uses the implicit finite difference scheme and the Thomas algorithm.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> text
input: How can the air temperature leaving the earth tube be calculated?
output: Once the node (ground) temperatures have been determined the air temperature leaving the earth tube can be calculated using the effectiveness-NTU formulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for effectiveness?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: How is the equation for effectiveness rearranged to find the temperature of the air leaving the earth tube?
output: The equation for effectiveness is rearranged to: \\( T_airin - T_airout = \\eta * (T_airin - T_et) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Zone Equipment and Zone Forced Air Units -> equation
input: What is the equation for the air outlet temperature?
output: The equation for the air outlet temperature is: \\( T_airout = T_airin - \\eta * (T_airin - T_et) \\)

Lopez-Alonzo C. Claridge D. E. and Kreider J. F. 1995. Analytical model to predict annual soil surface temperature variation. Journal of Solar Energy Engineering 117 91\textasciitilde99 Labs K. Renewable Energy 6 pp.893\textasciitilde900 \subsectionThermal Chimney Model\labelthermal-chimney-model The ZoneThermalChimney input object is available for modeling a thermal chimney which is a device that uses stack driven air movement to ventilate spaces within a building. These systems have been used successfully in buildings as small as the size of an outhouse up to large commercial buildings. The air within a thermal chimney is heated naturally using solar energy. The air increases in temperature which causes its density to drop. This drop in density results in a natural vertical movement of air and a local drop in pressure. The drop in pressure is relieved by drawing air from the building interior and the heat gained within the thermal chimney does not enter the occupied portion of the building. These systems are often used in support of natural ventilation systems. The EnergyPlus model will seek to model the air heat balance effects of the thermal chimney balance air movements caused by the thermal chimney and report other appropriate system variables. The new model will be linked into the air heat balance in a fashion similar to the current infiltration and simple ventilation models but will not be linked to an HVAC air loop.~ Any flow through the thermal chimney will be accounted for in the air mass balance in the HVAC calculations. However other sophisticated ventilation strategies can be handled by other existing EnergyPlus components. \emphtextbfInput Requirements \beginitemize \item
output: ```json
